text:
China’s economy has been struggling to reawaken
from an economic shutdown that was officially
ended last year.

Chinese authorities are now reported to be
pressuring economists and analysts within

the country to avoid discussing any negative
trends and to avoid using the word deflation,

as concerns grow about the leaderships’
ability to stimulate the economy.

In April consumer confidence fell back to
the lows of 2022, according to China’s National

Bureau of Statistics, which promptly stopped
releasing the figure.

Many people including me expected to see much
more of recovery in consumption in China as

the extreme lockdowns were brought to an end
last year and people returned to normal life.

In 2021 when the first lockdown ended in China,
we saw consumption grow around 9% along with
strong exports and strong business investment.

During that period Chinese GDP grew strongly
without a significant increase in the debt

burden, which implies that it was high quality
growth rather than GDP growth driven by malinvestment.

2022 which followed was obviously a terrible
year for China with the extreme lockdowns

that occurred particularly in cities like
Shanghai where residents couldn’t leave
their homes.

It seemed reasonable to expect some sort of
bounce back this year once the pandemic lockdowns
had ended.

Instead, we h ave seen month after month of
bad numbers, weak consumption, weak retail

sales, exports down a little and imports down
a lot, which is another sign of low consumption
in China.

The country’s property sector, which has
driven more than 25% of its GDP in recent

years, is in very rough shape – we have
discussed that for a number of years here
on this channel.

Property developers, who carry debts that
come to around 16% of Chinese GDP, are still
struggling to meet their obligations.

Two of them, Country Garden and Sino-Ocean,
have recently missed bond payments.

Entities linked to the conglomerate Zhongzhi
have failed to make payments, sparking concern

over the country’s wealth management industry
and its exposure to a troubled property market.

Zhongzhi is a diversified enterprise with
stakes in everything from financial businesses,
to mining companies to venture capital.

Its investments are estimated to come to at
least $140 billion US Dollars.

Zhongzhi holds a “strategic stake” in
Zhongrong International Trust, which last

week failed to repay the proceeds of two financial
products.

Trust companies like this one have historically
been an important source of financing for
the now struggling property sector.

Trouble at firms like this are worrying as
(for example) KBC Corporation, which manufactures

carbon composite products that are part of
the semiconductor supply chain have announced

that they have not received around $8.25 million
dollars from Zhongrong that they were due.

The worry is that if these trust companies
are hiding big losses there could be contagion

where losses from the property sector are
finding their way into other sectors of the
Chinese economy.

The Chinese government, facing an expected
seventh consecutive monthly increase in youth

unemployment, two weeks ago announced that
it was suspending the release of that data.

On top of this, the demographic problems brought
about by the one-child policy are growing.

Most economists agree that Chinese exports
are unlikely to grow this year as the global

economy is not exactly booming and China’s
trade with the United States, its best customer

shrank by 20% in July compared with a year
earlier.

America is both shunning exports from China
and restricting investment in China.

So, consumption is not recovering; the property
sector is unlikely to recover any time soon

(the government is currently demolishing unneeded
buildings) and the only remaining source of

growth is renewed infrastructure spending
which Beijing doesn’t want to do as the

country already has too much infrastructure
– and this is the big source of debt – and
malinvestment.

China’s once successful growth model – which
did work in the past when there was a huge

need for investment and infrastructure - stopped
working ten to fifteen years ago.

The country now needs to change gear and shift
to a new growth model, so, let’s look at

what China might do to recover from this slowdown,
let’s discuss the reduced tax on share trading

announced this morning and how the Chinese
slowdown might affect people in other countries
around the world.

A decade ago, China’s National Bureau of
Statistics provided a vast amount of economic

data – more than 80,000 time series were
made available for analysis – many people

questioned the accuracy of the data – but
it was made available.

Five years later the number of economic indicators
available had halved.

And they have halved again in the last five
years to fewer than twenty thousand time series.

Viewed in this context, the decision to suspend
the release of youth unemployment data seems

less surprising and is just the continuation
of a trend towards greater opacity as the
economy has been growing less.

A spokesman for the National Bureau of Statistics
in China told the press that the government

had stopped publishing this data as the surveys
“need to be further improved and optimized.”

China’s youth unemployment rate has doubled
in the last four years, as the economic volatility

during the pandemic made companies more wary
of hiring.

Worse yet, young Chinese university graduates
are 1.4 times more likely to be unemployed.

China Tobacco Henan – a State owned tobacco
factory - announced a few months ago that

almost a third of its new factory-floor hires
had postgraduate degrees, which triggered

national debate in China over whether these
highly educated young people were wasted on
the assembly line?

Or had they in fact make a smart decision
given the higher-than-average wages paid by
the company and the job stability provided.

Since 1999 there was a big push to educate
more of the workforce in China and higher

education expanded faster than market demand
for university graduates did, meaning that

there are more college graduates in China
than there are jobs to pay them and as a result

a high portion of Chinese youths are unemployed,
with others being underemployed – having
taken jobs that they are overqualified for.

As it stands right now the jobless rate of
16- to 24-year-olds hit 21.3 percent in June

(an all-time high) before reporting of the
data was suspended.

The political push to reduce negative economic
commentary from economists and analysts based

in China comes after a long series of disappointing
economic data points that have undermined

investor confidence and hindered Beijing’s
efforts to spur a robust rebound.

Last month, the Communist party’s politburo
admitted that the recovery was making “tortuous
progress”.

Since the unlock in December Chinese cities
have become busy once again with traffic jams
and so on.

There has been an increase in spending on
travel and catering, car sales are strong

– but this is tied to significant government
support, almost all other durable goods sales
are down a lot.

A somewhat interesting data point is that
there has been double digit growth in the

sales of gold and precious jewelry in China
so far this year.

According to the World Gold Council, Chinese
consumers bought 198 tons of gold jewelry

in the first quarter of 2023, the highest
number recorded since 2015, in the same quarter.

Gold purchases in China made up for 41% of
the global sales during this time.

Spending on jewelry like this could be viewed
as consumption, but it might equally be driven

by an urge to store wealth outside of the
financial system and nervousness over real
estate prices.

The world Gold Council note in their report
that Chinese retailers have moved to pricing

items on a per gramme of gold basis rather
than simply displaying the price of the finished

item, which possibly indicates that people
are buying jewelry as a store of wealth rather
than to wear.

When I was discussing this with a friend of
mine, she mentioned that these gold purchases

could be driven by a lack of trust in the
recently introduced central bank digital currency
in China.

At this point it’s all speculation as to
why people are doing what they are doing,
but this data might be worth monitoring.

Real estate is maybe the most important sector
in China.

As I mentioned earlier it represents over
25 percent of Chinese GDP and China's property

sector is in fact considered the world's largest
asset class with a value of 62 trillion dollars.

Real estate makes up two-thirds of private
household asset allocations compared to the
four percent allocated to equities.

The majority of Chinese household wealth is
tied to real estate.

Prices for existing properties in China’s
100 biggest cities have dropped by 14% compared
with their 2021 peaks.

When you consider that the typical downpayment
on a home in China is 24%, this means that

more than half of recent homebuyers’ wealth
has been wiped out.

That 14% drop is for the 100 biggest cities
in China.

I wasn’t able to get good data on real estate
performance in smaller cities, other than

finding reports that the big cities are performing
better than small cities are.

China is planning to guide mortgage financing
rates lower and reduce down-payment requirements
to help revive real estate prices.

The Minister of Housing and Urban-rural Development
recently told developers that more loosening

measures would be implemented to spur a market
recovery, given the sectors’ importance
and contribution to the nation’s economy.

As I mentioned in my recent video on real
estate affordability around the world, Chinese

homeowners already pay some of the highest
multiples of income of any country in the
world.

House prices being pushed up even higher does
not seem like it would make an awful lot of
sense.

Cutting rates and reducing down-payments might
be expected to revive a sluggish housing market

if households and businesses were eager to
buy property but unable to come up with the
capital.

The problem in China over the last few years
hasn’t been expensive mortgages restraining

buyers, but instead a growing realization
that real estate prices are no longer likely
to keep going up.

The only way lower mortgage rates would push
up real estate prices is if the new low rates

were to spark off fresh speculative demand
based on reviving the belief that home prices

can rise more than the economy grows going
forward.

Not only is that unlikely, but even if it
could be done, it would be economically harmful
in the long term.

China's residential real estate prices are
already at least 2-3 times what the size of
the economy can justify.

While some might hope that the situation rebalances
not through falling prices but rather through

steady real estate prices and rising GDP,
it would take more than thirty years of GDP
rising by 3-4% for this to happen.

That is a long time to wait for real estate
prices to become rational, and so there doesn’t

appear to be any way to avoid falling property
prices which will be very painful for Chinese
households.

The government would probably be better off
looking for ways to reduce the pain rather
than trying to avoid the unavoidable.

A real estate collapse in China would be quite
wide reaching within the economy, affecting

banks, households, investors suppliers and
workers in the construction industry.

According to a recent piece in The Economist,
China’s economic miracle is long over.

Its economy has matured, and its workforce
is shrinking.

They argue that business confidence has suffered
due to the “regulatory storm” that struck

the nation after 2020, humbling China’s
technology companies, like Alibaba, and all
but killing the ed-tech industry.

The various crackdowns and lockdowns left
the business community with the new belief

that the government is now willing to sacrifice
economic growth for other ends.

Falling confidence means that foreign direct
investment all but vanished in the second

quarter of 2023, falling by 87% year-on-year
to $4.9 billion dollars as multinationals

repatriated their earnings rather than reinvesting
them in the country.

Some analysts make the argument that while
debt loads in China are very high, the debt

is mostly internal, with external debt making
up only 14% of GDP compared to the United

States where external debt more than 95% of
GDP.

This possibly shows a lack of understanding
of debt, as who the debt is owed to doesn’t

really matter as much to a country as its
ability to service the debt.

The two biggest debt problems of the last
hundred years were the United States at the

end of the 1920’s and Japan at the end of
the 1980’s.

In both of these cases the debt was mostly
internal and that did nothing to dampen the
economic pain that followed.

There is an excellent blog post by Michael
Pettis of Peking University that I will link
to in the video description.

He points out that China currently invests
around 42–44 percent of its GDP, and that

it has invested a similar or larger percentage
for decades.
It’s high peaked at 47% in 2010.
This is an extraordinarily high percentage.

According to the World Bank, investment comprises
around 25 percent of global GDP.

For more mature, capital-intensive economies,
investment can make up roughly 15–20 percent

of GDP and for developing economies in the
midst of their high-growth stages, investment
levels tend to reach 30–35 percent of GDP.

Unbalanced economies that have traditionally
relied on high investment to drive growth,

such as South Korea and Taiwan, are also in
that 30-35% range.

A very high level of investment would have
made sense thirty years ago as the country

was starved of capital, and any money that
was invested was invested productively, where

the return on investment was greater than
the cost of capital and investors were rewarded
for the risk that they took.

When the economy reached a point where there
was more capital than good projects that could

use that capital and earn a return on it investment
rates should have fallen, but in China, because

the government targeted GDP growth rather
than return on investment, money continued

to be pumped in to build infrastructure that
was not needed and was pumped into the property

sector to build homes that people don’t
live in.

In a normal situation if you take $100 and
invest it in a project that yields $90 of

value – an asset that doesn’t create sufficient
cash flow to cover its cost, you are left
with a $10 loss which someone has to absorb.

In China local governments have taken on billions
of dollars of debt and are holding on their

books billions of dollars of assets that are
not worth their claimed value.

They don’t create sufficient cashflow to
service the debt, and this has gone on for
a long time.

This is what is known as malinvestment, the
losses associated with this huge malinvestment

are real- even if they are not being recognized,
and the hit eventually needs to be taken by
someone.

That could be the local government who built
a road to no where, it could be the central

government in Beijing who bails them out,
it could be the lenders, who lent against

an asset that is impaired, but the loss (which
is real) will eventually be allocated.

There are limited ways to grow an economy,
through increased investment (which is as

highlighted by Pettis already at an extreme),
through boosting consumption, which as I mentioned

at the start of this video is not happening
right now, or through increased trade surpluses,

which the rest of the world – in particular
the United States are fighting back against.

As investment declines from the extreme levels
it is currently at, Chinas GDP growth depends
mainly on consumption growth.

Replacing investment driven growth with consumption
driven growth in a seamless manner is something
which has never happened in any country before.

For consumption to surge with investment and
GDP growth dropping sharply, some external

factor would need to directly or indirectly
drive-up growth in household income.

Pettis argues that this could happen if China
were, to transfer roughly 1–2 percentage

points of GDP every year from local governments
and wealthy individuals or the business sector
to ordinary households.

The problem with trying to do this is that
these large transfers would be politically

difficult to manage without major changes
in the country’s economic, financial, and
political institutions.

There are all sorts of ways that a government
can reallocate wealth within an economy such

as reducing payroll taxes, reducing fees that
individuals pay like road tolls, improving

the pension system, improving the quality
of social healthcare – basically leaving

workers with more of what they earn so that
they can spend it – boosting business.

Some economists have argued that the government
should buy up some of the unsold inventories

of China’s struggling property developers
in order to create affordable rental housing
for the poor.

All of these would cost the government but
would mean that citizens have more money to
spend.

None of this seems particularly likely as
while policy makers in China do appear to

recognize the need to boost consumption, they
voice a lot of concern about any transfers
making the workers lazy.

This morning Beijing cut a tax on stock trading
for the first time since the 2008 financial

crisis, in an attempt to boost the stock market
and investor confidence.

Chinese stocks initially jumped five and a
half percent, but then closed just 1.2 per
cent higher by the end of the day.

By comparison, Chinese stocks closed up more
than 9 percent the day after the levy was
last cut in 2008.

A change like this would matter much more
to traders than long term investors.

Right now, there is no clear action plan from
the Chinese government.

The most likely outcome is of course that
policy makers make very few changes until
economic reality forces them to.

It’s impossible to keep such a high investment
share for ever, a country can’t spend its

way to higher growth, building infrastructure
that is both unnecessary and expensive to
maintain.

China will eventually need to rebalance to
get debt under control and the losses of malinvestment

will eventually be recognized and allocated,
we don’t know to who.

A slowdown in China, or a real estate collapse
is unlikely to have a huge impact on investors
in the rest of the world.

Despite the warnings from some market commentators
a Chinese real estate collapse or debt crisis

would be nothing like the US real estate collapse
in 2008 simply because the Chinese economy
is quite isolated from the rest of the world.

They have been very protectionist with their
investment opportunities, and restrictive
of what they import from other countries.

China does buy in raw materials and certain
technology products, and a number of developing

countries do have significant business ties
to China, but despite any fearmongering you

might read in the press, there is no reason
to expect a rerun of 2008.

Western companies have started announcing
their worries about how a slowdown in China
would affect their businesses.

China has provided a booming market for products
from chemicals to luxury goods to healthcare
and travel.

“The major drive” behind Agilent’s revenue
drop in the latest quarter was the lab instrument

maker’s business in China, according to
Agilent’s CEO Mike McMullen, prompting the
company to lower its annual growth targets.

German industrial conglomerate Siemens said
there had been a sharp drop in new orders

in China, particular in its factory automation
business.

There are sectors that do have lots of exposure
to China, but it is mostly an exporting nation

rather than importing and they do have capital
controls that have mostly kept westerners
from investing in China in any great size.

The Economist argues that Xi Jinping prizes
greatness over growth, security over efficiency

and resilience over comfort and that he wants
to fortify the economy, not gratify consumers.

Such an approach might lead to a hard landing
for China.

For investors in the rest of the world, it
is of course worthwhile paying attention to

the goings on in the world’s second largest
economy, and thinking about which companies

sell the most to China but the most important
thing is to take a long-term view when it

comes to investing, and not getting shaken
out when you hear stories of a slowdown.
